body:
Comment 2 by **cole.mickens**: 
That's basically exactly what my script is doing. In fact, if you use those scripts and
do the `buildpkg windows 386` as it suggests, you will have a functioning cross compiler
for that target. If you then do `buildpkg linux 386`, you will have a functioning
linux/386 cross-compiler, but it breaks the windows/386 cross compiler in the process.

The problem stems from the fact that the cross compilers rely on some generated header
files that are cleaned up on subsequent builds and those only available for the last
generated cross compiler.
